title: Canada's oddest big roadside attractions [Photos]
text:
Monday, August 31, 2015 07:00 AM CDT Canada's oddest big roadside attractions Previous Next 
Colborne, Ontario: This community is home to the "Big Apple," an attraction that stands at 10.7 metres and includes a restaurant and observation deck. (Tom Van Dusen/Postmedia Network) 
Sydney, Nova Scotia: Sydney lays claim to the "Largest Ceilidh Fiddle in the World." Located on the Sydney waterfront, the fiddle stands 16 metres tall. (Google Street View) 
Campbellton, New Brunswick: This stainless steel statue depicts a salmon leaping from the water. It stands 8.5 metres tall. ( Gzhao/Wikipedia ) 
Lloydminster, Alberta: This giant sundial can be located within the city's Bud Miller All Seasons Park. It is 60 metres across and reads local time. (Google Street View) 
Portage La Prairie, Manitoba: Billed as the world's largest Coke can, this roadside attraction was constructed from an old water tower. (Rob Swystun/Postmedia Network) 
St. Thomas, Ontario: The statue of the elephant Jumbo was erected in this small Ontario town after the elephant, travelling with P.T. Barnum's circus, was crushed by a locomotive in the St. Thomas marshalling yard. (Nick Lypaczewski/Postmedia Network) 
Kamloops, B.C.: This 4.5 metres long wooden trout was erected in honour of Kamloops' centennial celebrations and the 1993 World Fly Fishing Championships. (Courtesy Kamloops Chamber of Commerce) 
Sudbury, Ontario: The Big Nickel is a popular tourist attraction in this northern Ontario city. It is a replica of a 1951 nickel and is listed by Guinness Book of World Records as the world's largest coin. (John Lappa/Postmedia Network) 
Kenora, Ontario: This 12-metre-tall muskellunge fish is known affectionately as Huskie the Muskie and is located along the Trans-Canada Highway. (Postmedia Network) 
Vegreville, Alberta: The world's largest Ukranian Easter egg, or pysanka , was built in Vegreville in honour of the 100th anniversary of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. (Wikipedia/Myke Waddy) 
Shediac, New Brunswick: This lobster is 10.7 metres long and 4.9 metres high. The Shediac Rotary Club led the construction of the giant lobster to honour the city's rich ocean-based economy. ( Wikipedia/JAKclapclap47 ) 
O'Leary, P.E.I.: This potato, located in front of the local Potato Museum, is 4.2 metres tall. (Courtesy Prince Edward Island Potato Museum) 
Vulcan, Alberta: To honour its coincidental Star Trek connection, Vulcan has constructed a themed tourist station, complete with a replica of the Starship Enterprise. (Al Charest/Postmedia Network) 
Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan: Mac the Moose has represented Moose Jaw since 1984. At 9.8 metres tall and located just off the Trans-Canada Highway, Mac is one of the city's most popular tourist attractions. ( Wikipedia/Flickr/SriMesh ) 
Drumheller, Alberta: There are numerous dinosaur statues around Drumheller, most notably this 25-metre-tall Tyrannosaurus Rex. (Courtesy Royal Tyrell Museum) 
Altona, Manitoba: This easel, along with the Vincent van Gogh "Sunflowers" painting replica, were created by Cole Jared Nickel. The Guinness Book of World Records named it the world's tallest easel in 1998. (Google Street View) 
Wawa, Ontario: The Wawa goose is an iconic tourist attraction in the area. The statue is 8.5 metres tall. (Joe Warmington/Postmedia Network) 
Beaverlodge, Alberta: This beaver sculpture is 4.6 metres tall and 5.4 metres long. ( Wikipedia/Qyd ) 
Dunnville, Ont.: Dunnville's beloved 52-footlong Muddy the Mudcat statue on Highway 3. (Matt Day/Postmedia Network) Article
